FacilityName: Borough of Phoenixville Wastewater Treatment Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Borough of Phoenixville owns and operates a 4.0-MGD wastewater treatment plant located on Second Avenue in Phoenixville, Chester County, PA.  The wastewater collected within the Borough and some parts of Schuylkill Township is treated using the activated sludge process and the plant effluent is disinfected with chlorine gas prior to discharge to the Schuylkill River.  The plant is staffed with nine full time employees under the supervision of Mr. Matthew Mullin, Wastewater Plant Superintendent.  Mr. Donald Edwards, P.E., Borough Manager/Engineer has overall responsibility for the wastewater system and the water system as well.

One full one ton chlorine cylinder and one partially full (~100-200 lbs) one-ton chlorine cylinder are on site at any given time.  One cylinder is in service with one 150 pound cylinder on standby.  An automatic switchover system transfers chlorine to the 150-pound chlorine cylinder.

The worst case release of chlorine gas at the facility consists of a catastrophic release of 2000 pounds of the gas from a one ton container over a 10-minute period at a rate of 200 lbs/min.  The container is located inside the chlorine room at the facility.  No credit has been taken for any mitigating factors in calculating the extent of the release.  The estimated distance to the toxic end point of 0.087 mg/l is 1.3 miles, and an estimated residential population of 5000 would be affected.  The toxic end point was calculated using EPA Document No. 550-B-98-010 dated October 1998 entitled, ?Risk Management Program Guidance For Wastewater Treatment Plants (40 CFR Part 68).  The population figures were estimated.

The alternative release scenario for chlorine gas consists of a leak created by a faulty valve mounted on the cylinder.  Although unlikely to occur, this release scenario is more likely to occur than the worst case scenario described above.  The maximum distance to toxic end point is estimated at 0.3 miles.  The toxic end point was obtained from the

same EPA Document described n the previous paragraph.

The staff at the facility follows procedures that include daily inspections of the chlorine system, periodic safety training programs and quarterly inspection and repair/replacement program of the chlorination equipment by an outside agency.  The staff also takes advantage of the Operator Outreach Program of the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection to continually update their skills in maintaining and safely operating the system.  A safety review of the facility is also conducted by the Borough?s insurance carrier on an annual basis.  The most recent review was held on December 16, 2004.

The facility has had one accidental release of chlorine gas in the past five years on July 22, 2000 whereby approximately 552 lbs of chlorine gas was released.

A written emergency response plan approved by the Local Emergency Planning Committee of the County of Chester is updated on an annual basis.

The Borough is currently engaged in a planned upgrade to the facility that will include ultraviolet disinfection, eliminating the need for storage of any chlorine cylinders onsite.
